characters: INT. JOSHUA TREE FUNERAL HOME. DAY
EXT. OUTSIDE JOSHUA TREE INN. DAWN
EXT. OUTSIDE LARRY OSTERBERG'S GARAGE. DAY
EXT. OUTSIDE THE POLYONAX PLACE. DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A phone rings in the dark. A little light falls from the open window, illuminating an old bakelite telephone. It sits on a small table alongside a large amount of empty bottles and a couple of overflowing ashtrays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A three wheeled motorcycle is being driven through the night at great speed. The trike is moving very quickly, its headlights cutting through the darkness, its wheels sending a spray of sand flying towards us, as the driver fights to keep it on the road. This is PHIL KAUFMAN, and he's in a hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two figures are struggling on the floor. The male is naked. The woman sits astride him, her movements urgent, her breath fast. They appear to be having sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Trike cuts through the night, and we pull back to sho desert, more desert, and then... a giant bright, flickeri neon sign: 'Welcome to the Joshua Tree Inn'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That phone - still ringing; shrill, insistent. There is a bed next to the table. It is covered in clothes, but ther is also a man's shape, which now moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little more light, and it now appears as if our man and woman are struggling. There is fear on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still that insistent ringing, and the covers suddenly fly off the bed. We see the man from behind as he shakes the sleep away and looks for the damn phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman is screaming now, and banging on the man's ches with her fists. He is motionless underneath her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Trike skids to a halt amid a cloud of dust and the driver leaps off. He runs at the door, throwing it open i one movement, disappearing into the room. A broken stripe 'No Entry - Police' band flutters to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man finally answers the phone.   At last the ringing stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door bounces back open, and we can see the Phil walki quickly through the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he searches, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God please help me! I found your number in his pocket and I don't know... I don't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, what... who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead... he's dead... and I'm... just... I don't know what to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man glances into the bathroom and opens some drawers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on.   Tell me who's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parsons. Gram Parsons. We met in a bar and we had a lot to drink and he just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure he's dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks under the beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. He's really dead.    He just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. Call an ambulance. Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joshua Tree. Joshua Tree Inn. Room eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He checks on top of the wardrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got a car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call an ambulance. Then get out of there. Okay? Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay. I'm goin'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He picks up a sheet of paper from the bedside table and glances at it. He turns and walks past us to the car and for the first time we see Phil Kaufman's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Trike skids to a halt outside the small white hospita There are a couple of press vehicles parked outside, and reporter is recording a piece to camera in the background Phil sits for a moment, and then opens the door and walks to the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move through the reception area up to the nurses' station. Phil is in conversation with a large woman in a nurse's uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wanna run that by me again, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I'd like to see Gram Parsons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to see Gram Parsons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Alone, if possible. And would you have a gurney standing by in case I need to move him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks carefully at the pyjamas which peek out from under the shabby overcoat. His hair is on end. He is wearing biker boots and is holding an unlit but half-smok cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you are.... his physician? Or perhaps a close relative?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I'm his road manager.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The big nurse smiles mirthlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're not his physician or a close relative?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Parsons is awaiting a post mortem. He will then be delivered to his family. I suggest you speak to them if you wish to pick through his personal effects. Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now listen here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you listen here. Mister Parsons is dead and no longer appears to need a road manager. Which makes two of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The nurse turns and marches down the corridor. Phil waits until she's gone and then walks through a door marked 'Admittance only to Authorized Hospital Staff'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil slips off his overcoat and stuffs it into the trash. He tosses away the unlit cigar, grabs a white coat from a hook and puts it on. He walks out through another door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil wanders down the corridor, glancing into rooms and checking signs. He pushes open a door marked 'Pathology'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is empty, except for a couple of covered bodies trolleys. Phil checks under the first sheet, and recoils at whatever it is which lies beneath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheesh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks over to the next gurney and lifts the sheet.   H stares down at the body, visibly moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello buddy. How you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands for a moment, gripping the gurney and looking down at his friend. Then he snaps out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't stand around here chatting with you all day. Things to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wheels the gurney towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil wheels the gurney down the corridor towards the exit A doctor in green scrubs approaches and glances down at a clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Naw, I'm cool thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor reads the tag on the body's toe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just taking some stiff down to neurology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have a neurology department.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Urology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor grabs the end of the gurney. Phil tugs and the doctor tugs back. After a moment, Phil sighs and shakes his head in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Just hold your horses - I'll go check the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor holds up his clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have the paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You have your paperwork. I need to go check my paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He slips through the exit. The doctor waits awkwardly a few seconds, and then pushes open the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?   Hello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances around in surprise, but there is no-one in sight.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DESERT. MORNING
dialogues.text: Phil's trike accelerates as it approaches a T junction. the right the sign points to 'Joshua Tree Town', to the left 'Los Angeles'. The trike doesn't even slow as it skids left, sending a spray of sand and gravel flying across the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NB. There will be several shots of Phil driving through the desert, set to music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Trike pulls up outside a rambling old house. Two enormous plaster eagles flank the front door, a giant Harley Davidson sign hangs from the roof, and there's a s foot flashing neon star in the front window. Phil gets out, walks up to the door and pulls some keys out of his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil walks into the room and pours himself a drink. He slumps onto the couch, takes a sip and closes his eyes. W see movement behind him, as an attractive girl slips through a door and approaches Phil from behind. This is SUSIE, and she puts her hands over his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martin Luther King.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie leans over the back of the chair and gives Phil a long slow kiss. She jumps over the couch and resumes kissing, this time more passionately. Phil tries to pull away with little success.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This.... ...isn't.... ...the best time... ...Baby....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie continues regardless, Phil is now finding it hard t resist. He eventually gives in, and they begin to kiss passionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Susie are sitting at the kitchen table.   He tak a drag from her cigarette and passes it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God damn!     I'm so sorry, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, out of a job again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would never have happened if you were there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know I wasn't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you were, you wouldn't have let him die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was still 'on staff'. He was still my responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit quietly for a moment.      Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where have you been, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sighs, and stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long this time? Two weeks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, let's have this conversation again. Like you haven't just done six weeks on the road...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I usually leave a note. And there's a paycheck involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie disappears through the door. Phil's shoulders sag and he slumps against the wall. Then Susie reappears with a bottle of Jack Daniels and a couple of glasses. She pours out two generous measures and hands one to Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, he gets up and follows her out of the roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie guides Phil to a chair and sits him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a remembrance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She crosses to a record player and turns it on, pausing t let down the blind on the way back. 'In My Hour of Darkness'(or similar music) fills the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Earnestly) He was so beautiful, and he understood what my heart was feeling. I'll...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: never laugh again. My inner joy has gone. It evaporated when Gram departed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sang country music in a way that it had never been sung before. It was 'country rock', if you like. And it was kinda catchy. At least, the young people seemed to lap it up. It's fair to say that when Gram Parsons died, he died a star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like... I can't... It was real, kinda... I... Oh, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And another light burns out in the desert. Gram Parsons - the standard bearer of the new country music movement - is dead, following an overdose of drugs. While many of America's young people are today in mourning, their parents will view this as another example of how today's drug culture can so easily claim a life. We'll leave you tonight with the young man's own words. Gram Parsons wrote a song called 'In My Hour of Darkness', which contains these words: 'In my hour of darkness...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are back in Phil's sitting room. Fade up on the music, to match the reporter's words, as Gram's voice fills the room: (or similar music).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my hour of darkness, in my time of need, Oh Lord grant me vision, Oh Lord grant me speed. Oh Lord grant me vision, Oh Lord grant me speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie tenderly throws a blanket over the sleeping Phil as the record ends. She turns the light off and the room goe dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie walks in with a coffee. She sits beside Phil and strokes his head until he wakes. She kisses him and passe him the cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits up and stretches. She leans over to kiss him, the stands and starts to tidy. He watches her. She picks up some clothing from near his chair and moves away. He drop another piece of clothing on the same spot. She says nothing and picks it up. He takes a sock off and drops it It has stopped being a game and started being a statement She picks the sock up and drops it in his lap. He pushes it back onto the floor. She opens her arms and everything falls to the floor. She walks out of the room and into th kitchen. He follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie leans on the table, staring out of the window.   Ph walks up behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you're here, I spend my time wondering when you're going. And when you're back, I wonder where you've been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns and walks round to face him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil, you give me laughs and a great time. But I'm not sure if that's enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean there's more than that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, there's more than that! There's dependable, responsible, reliable...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's dull, boring, normal. You should hook up with someone who works in a bank. I know a guy, actually. He has fish for dinner every Friday, cleans his shoes twice a week and buys his ties in bulk because it works out cheaper that way. I'll put you in touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind loving a crazy bastard, Phil. But you've got to be for something and not just against everything. You have to choose something to represent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I represent the combined forces of charm, enchantment and exuberance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your job is to arrange other people's lives. Maybe it's time to put a little thought into your own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie walks out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A suburban street of small, neat bungalows. We move down the street, past house and identical house, until we rest outside another that is identical to the rest. The front door opens, and a nondescript man emerges, carrying a sma overnight bag. He carefully locks the door and walks down the path to where a cab waits. We can clearly see 'New Orleans Taxi' marked on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Airport, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is STANLEY PARSONS, Gram's father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a loud banging on the front door. Phil glances out of the window, and looks momentarily puzzled. He open the door, and a beautiful woman stands on the step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long time, no see, Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try and schmooze me, Kaufman, you repellent slimeball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She notices Susie standing behind Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The latest victim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara walks past them into the kitchen.      Susie look quizzically at Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara calls out from the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a lot tidier than I remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie raises an eyebrow at Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gram's ex-girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil points at his temple as if to say she's nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Girlfriend? Isn't he married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara walks back into the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the seventies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want, Barbara?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to fulfill Gram's wishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waits for him to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice. I have no idea what you're talking about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds up an old piece of writing paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what this is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil reaches for it, but Barbara snatches it away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Gram's will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She reads it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To whom it may concern: I would like it to be known that it is my wish to leave Barbara Mansfield my assets and belongings in the event of my death. Signed: Ingram Cecil Parsons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil looks surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he write that with joined up writing or was it before he knew how?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara gives a wry smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still the jester Kaufman, and still very unfunny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a will Barbara, and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's better than a will, actually. It's a signed promise from Gram to leave me all his assets and belongings. And anyway, it's really none of your business what this is. I've come for the guitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guitar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Gram's guitar.   He always kept it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been a while since you were around, Barbara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gretchen, his wife, took it back six months ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara leans forward until their noses are almost touching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe you, Kaufman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara pushes past Phil who gives no resistance. She walks straight over to the couch and starts pulling up th cushions. Susie moves to stop her, but Phil holds her bac and lets Barbara carry on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and Susie sit on the sofa, an island of calm in a se of chaos. Around them, the floor is covered with papers, clothing, empty record covers, torn open cushions and books. A broken drawer is propped against the table. A lampshade hangs crazily from its bearings, throwing stran shadows around the room. Suddenly, Susie gets up and kick a cushion across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, well done. You found the only unbroken thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you let her in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all part of the grieving process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can she behave that way? Gram's not even in the ground yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues to look at her oddly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you freak out on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do me a favor and get the guitar, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disappears into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta make a call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man with glasses and an ill-fitting black suit does som paperwork. He is surrounded by coffins displaying garish 'special offer' price tickets. The phone rings, and the undertaker takes his time answering it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon.     Joshua Tree Obsequies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is holding the phone.         He frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Obsequies? What the hell does that mean? I'm...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the rest of Phil's mutter from the phone in the undertaker's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Latin. It means burial. Is there anything I can help with? Who am I speaking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil straightens up.         He speaks curtly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, you can help me as a matter of fact. I am...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, we hear Phil's voice trumpeting out of the phone. The undertaker changes his tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Parsons? I'm sorry, I'll take a look immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts down the phone and flicks through a big book. purses his lips. He wipes his nose with a white silk handkerchief. Then he picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he was here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New Orleans. Although he only just went, so he'll still be on his way to Los Angeles Airport. Big thrill for us here, as we're only a small facility. Nearly got Jane Mansfield in '67 when she passed through, but she got diverted to Frisco. Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No mutter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.    Hellooo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone sits on the table but the room is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie walks in, looks around, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PHIL'S DRIVEWAY. DAY
dialogues.text: Phil is lying down in the back of Susie's station wagon, his feet sticking out of the back. Susie comes out of the house carrying the guitar, and sits on the steps, where s watches him. After a minute:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These things aren't that big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.    Is that a problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Susie is confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No answer.      Phil continues to check out the inside of car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you up to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's best you don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Without a word, Susie gets up and walks into the house. Phil lies still. After a moment, she reappears with her bag. She flounces theatrically past him and opens the car door. Phil gets out of the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what this madness is, but I'm not getting involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I don't know what it is you're planning, but I'm not bailing you out again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets into the car and slams the door. She starts the engine, and Phil stands back, but the car doesn't move. After a moment the window winds down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time, I'm not coming back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gives him a 'so there' smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to find a man who buys his ties in bulk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drives away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil arrives on his trike outside a small house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man is sitting cross-legged on the floor. A joss stick burns beside him, and sitar music plays in the background This is LARRY OSTERBERG, and he is meditating. There is a loud hammering on the door. Larry shows no sign of having heard anything. More hammering at the door, but still no response. Then the letter box creaks open and an eye appears in the slot. After a moment, the eye disappears and Phil's face appears momentarily at the window. The window seems to be slightly higher than Phil, so his face appears every time he jumps up to peer into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (O.S) Hello? Anyone there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then Phil is gone. Larry expels a big breath. The letterbox creaks opens again and the eye is back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (O.S) There you are. I'm looking for Larry Osterberg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry sighs, and stretches. He gets up slowly, gently shakes himself to relax his muscles and walks to the door which he opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is unlocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil barrels in and closes the door behind him.   He turn to take a look around the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You Larry Osterberg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   Welcome to my house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This might be sarcastic, but any nuance is lost on Phil, who props the guitar up against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very nice.     What's that noise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Manomanjari on the sitar by Nikhil Banerjee. (NB. Similar music may be used in this scene) Phil stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully) Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pops a cigar into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no smoking in here, I'm afraid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil stares meaningfully at the burning joss stick, but puts the cigar away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm Phil Kaufman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how may I help you, Phil Kaufman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to hire your car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I need to pick someone up at the airport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know anyone with a car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. It's just that I'm told your car is more suitable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. In what way is my car more suitable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... it's a hearse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both look at each other.         Larry waits for Phi speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how is a hearse going to be suitable for picking someone up from the airport?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's... a joke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A joke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't look entirely convinced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A prank.   A surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, okay. Is it two hundred dollars worth of surprise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's more of a fifty dollar surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can lend you a bicycle. Besides, the car is booked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Booked how?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I use it to carry equipment for a band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil pulls some cash out of his pocket and sorts through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here's two hundred dollars to unbook it. Let 'em carry their own trombones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil passes the money over.   Larry starts to count it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need to count it.   You could trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry doesn't pause counting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see; I've never met you in my life, you shout through my mail slot, you want to hire my hearse as a joke, and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: you're twenty dollars short.   Why should I trust you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That last twenty is for gas. Anyway - I haven't even seen the car yet. I'm the one who's operating on trust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hearse. What else do you need to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The garage doors swing open and a hearse drives out into the sun. It is bright yellow and covered in painted flowers. One of the side windows is broken and a headligh hangs out. Phil's jaw drops open. Larry gets out of the driving seat and pats the roof, proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet Bernice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bernice is a Cadillac Superior Royale Tiara Limousine Funeral Coach. We've got a Seven gallon V8 engine offering three hundred and forty bhp at four thousand six hundred revolutions per minute. You're looking at a twenty one feet beauty with a one hundred and fifty six inch wheelbase containing a four barrel Rochester Quadrajet carburetor with Turbo Hydramatic transmission. Bernice weighs over six thousand pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a very long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's yellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's yellow.    Bernice comes in yellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's supposed to be black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they're all black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That might be my point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how is a yellow hearse covered with flowers less of a surprise than a black hearse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I paid you two hundred dollars for a black hearse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patiently) No, you paid me a hundred and eighty dollars for a hearse, and a hearse is what you've got. If you take a long, hard look at Bernice, you'll see that she's one of a kind. She's big, she's fast, she's comfortable, and she's beautiful. But she's not black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at each other for a moment.       Then Phil si deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Where are the keys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry looks from Phil to Bernice and back again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. She doesn't go anywhere without me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil thinks this over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   Well, let's boogie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry runs across and closes the doors on a pile of amps and band equipment that now sits in the garage. Phil puts the guitar in the back seat and they get into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry pulls a screwdriver out of the glove compartment an jigs it about in the ignition until the engine catches.

dialogues.speaker: CON TINUE D
dialogues.text: Then he turns the keys and pull up and down to undo the steering lock. Phil watches curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone stole her last summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I've paid top dollar, so it's nice to see I'm getting the best...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you hear of Bernice and me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are famous throughout the greater Los Angeles area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry looks pleased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you are the only guy with a hearse. Don't go getting carried away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One backfire, and Bernice is ready. The hearse weaves erratically across the road and then disappears in a clou of exhaust smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara sits at a table in her shabby kitchen, reading th will. She lights a cigarette and sits back in her chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hearse drives under a huge sign which reads 'Welcome Los Angeles Airport' and peels off the main road past som offices and cargo stores. Bernice drives into a giant hangar and pulls up outside a dark and shuttered office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil glances out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry parks, and Phil looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... What flight are they on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll wait here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, what time is the flight due?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   How soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you ask so many damn questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is silence.         Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouldn't we be at arrivals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, will you please shut up asking me stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks out of the window, and then back at Phil, who no has his eyes closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how long are we going to wait?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil doesn't answer for a moment.      Just as Larry open mouth to ask again, Phil speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry looks at Phil with astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning?   What do you mean, morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll make the pick-up in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry tries to start the car. Phil leans over and plucks the screwdriver from his hand. He reclines his seat and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You wait till morning.   I'm going home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry opens the door and gets out of the car. He slams th door shut behind him and stomps off into the gloom. Phil doesn't move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drivers' door opens and Larry gets back into the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only back because I don't trust you with Bernice. I don't even know you, and if you think I'm going to leave my car with you and just walk away, then you've got another thought on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at Phil, who hasn't moved an inch: eyes still closed, unlit cigar hanging out of the corner of his mout feet up on the dash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm staying right here. Where I can keep an eye on things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is still no response from Phil. After a moment, Larry settles back in his seat and closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hearse disappears into the gloom as the light fades a night falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door swings open, and Barbara appears. She is looking quite stunning, with a tight black suit doing equal justi to her womanly curves and her duties as a mourner. She strides down the sidewalk, and as a group of schoolchildr appears around the corner Barbara scatters left and right

dialogues.speaker: CON TINUE D
dialogues.text: Then she cuts across the road, and a delivery van skids t a halt inches away, horn blaring. The driver leans out of the window, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, lady!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara stops and whips round, her hair cascading across her shoulders, her blue eyes flashing. The man simply stares at her, enchanted by her beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues to stare, and is only shaken back to his senses by a burst of abuse from further back in the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... should be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, thank you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley is standing at the Airport Airlines check-in desk facing the check-in clerk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parsons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk checks her paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've just arrived from New Orleans, mister Parsons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're flying directly back to New Orleans? On the same plane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk awaits an explanation, but none is forthcoming. She raises an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, enjoy your stay at Los Angeles Airport, Mister Parsons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley turns to go, but then pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've come to pick up my son's body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line behind him falls quiet, and the officious clerk wobbles slightly. Stanley raises his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My son died out here, you see? So I've come to bring him home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks at Stanley.            Stanley looks at th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm wondering if that's enough information for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes. I'm sorry. We'll... see to it that you get every assistance on your journey, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a line leading to the information desk, but Barbara ignores it. She walks up to a female teller, who is serving another customer, and cuts in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to see the manager, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait your turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara's eyes immediately water, and her lower lip trembles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It's just that the man I loved died yesterday. I was forgetting my manners...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dabs at her eyes with a lace handkerchief. customer looks embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.     Please... go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara fixes the teller with a no-nonsense look.   The teller responds with a similar look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The manager?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man unlocks the shutters with a clatter and goes inside

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound wakes Phil, who glances around and stretches, before getting out of the car.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OUTSIDE MORTUARY. MORNING
dialogues.text: Phil walks over to the door and walks inside the mortuary

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk busies himself opening up. Phil wanders around and knocks into a coffin. The lid bangs closed and the sound echoes around the hangar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here to pick up a... coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk looks Phil over. He's dressed in denim, with scuffed Harley-Davidson cowboy boots, topped off with a c down denim jacket with 'Sin City' stitched into the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You're here to pick up a casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil looks irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.   A casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What flight number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It   was due out on the next flight to   New Orleans, but I'm driving it   now. The stiff doesn't like to   fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're one of those funny guys, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but it's my day off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine or the...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deceased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil moves to the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parsons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk turns and shouts over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney - bring up Parsons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bank Manager is staring at the piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I simply can't give you any money based on this piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is totally calm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a piece of paper. It's a promise from Gram to leave me all his money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm sorry, but it's highly likely that the estate will go to probate and be divided up accordingly, subject to a valid will existing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She just looks at him.      He tries again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Parsons was a customer of ours. We can't just pass his money across to someone who says they're in the will. There are... rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara, realizing that she's getting nowhere, starts to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't seem to understand. These are his wishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is now sobbing, and the bank manager is becoming increasing uncomfortable. He gives her his handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I do... understand, Miss Mansfield. Really I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please tell me how I'm supposed to get my money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I imagine that you first need to prove that mister Parsons is actually dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying that I'm lying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, absolutely not. But getting a copy of the death certificate would probably be a good first step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley takes a swig from a hip flask and looks out of th window. A very overweight, red-faced man squeezes into th next seat. He bangs Stanley with his knee as he sits, but Stanley doesn't move. He peers at Stanley and shuffles in his seat, but there is still no reaction. Next, a deep sigh is forced out between his fat wet lips - he is plain keen to start a conversation. Stanley keeps looking out o the window. He is watching the cargo being loaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paw on the space, don'tcha think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley turns slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fat man smiles and extends a chubby hand, which Stanl shakes awkwardly and reluctantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: P J Gambrell, at yer assistance. Pernell Jayson. Jes' saying paw on the space in dese buckets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley is obviously having problems fully understanding what is being said. After a moment:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley Parsons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gowna be a trip. Besta know yer otherwise gowna be a slow one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   I suppose so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk scribbles on a form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Papers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll be along. With this being a rush job, they said you'd understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He passes a folded banknote across.      The clerk pocket without a change of expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you'd better tell them that we've got rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men stare at each other. Then Phil pulls another note out of his pocket and passes that over. Again, the clerk pockets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is the exception which proves that particular rule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.   Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Although you don't need to tell them that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil smiles broadly at him. The clerk turns and selects a casket from a gurney behind the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this... is your deceased.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is wheeling a casket on a gurney down the middle of the hangar. He can see Larry peering through the window a him. He can also see a uniformed policeman approaching Larry from the other side of the street. As he speeds up to try and reach Larry first, the clerk calls out from hi desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil closes his eyes and slows to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is jumping up and down nervously outside the window The policeman appears at his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir.    Is that your hearse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry turns slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop points at Bernice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That hearse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry has started to sweat profusely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That hearse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop looks at him carefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay?   Sure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans against the window for support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley is looking out of the plane's window, but the fat man is now locked on. He gestures around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jes sayin' 'bout the space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another thoughtful pause from Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He glances out at the cargo loaders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Space ma game, kinda. Partitions. Fixed. Slidin'. Demountable. Integrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always say. Why have one room? When you can have two?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He leans forward to watch a loader wheeling a casket towards the back of the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your bidness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley watches the coffin and doesn't answer. A tear rolls down his face. The fat man pulls some candy out of his pocket and takes a bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil and the clerk peer into the open casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.   That's a she.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And yours is supposed to be male?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk walks back to the counter and peers at his paperwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...    Gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone?    Whaddya mean, gone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got the wrong box.      Your box is being loaded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice work.     So how do I get my box back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk raises an eyebrow.         Phil understands imm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a damn thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very hurtful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil reluctantly hands another note over and the clerk speaks into a radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney.    You receiving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is standing by the hearse.          The cop is read license.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, whatcha doin' here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doing?    Here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley has his eyes closed. The fat man eats. Suddenly, Stanley's eyes snap open and he peers out of the window. motorized cart chugs into view with the casket covered in blanket on the back. It is driving away from the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands up and turns to the fat man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to get off the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fat man reluctantly struggles to his feet and squeeze out into the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sheesh.    Only jes' got settled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil glances nervously out to where Larry is being interrogated by the cop. The clerk is reading a paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you speed things up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the hurry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is distracted, watching the cop and Larry out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to get to the Joshua Tree while it's still light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were taking him to New Orleans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you came in, you said you were driving the casket out to New Orleans. But just now you said you were headed for the Joshua Tree...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil is under pressure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joshua Tree, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A buzzer sounds.         No-one moves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joshua Tree, Louisiana. Just outside the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never heard of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's small. Just another local community struggling to get by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The buzzer goes again, and Phil attempts to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Use your phone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a moment, the clerk nods towards the phone on the desk, before turning and disappearing into the rear of th mortuary. Phil wipes some sweat from his forehead, picks up the phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: INT. PHIL'S LOUNGE. MORNING
dialogues.text: Susie is packing. The phone rings and she hesitates for a moment. Then she continues loading her case, leaving the phone unanswered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley tries to ask a question at the check in desk, but gives up and walks toward an exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk returns with a casket on a gurney and Phil replaces the receiver as the clerk flips open the top of the casket and peers inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into casket) Hello there. We was looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wheels the casket over and Phil has a quick look insid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need you to sign for it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil signs the papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like it's your lucky day after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.   I'm a real lucky guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil again glances out of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop is wandering around the hearse.    Larry trails behind him, disconsolately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like the look of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (miserably) No. Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wherever there's a hippie there's a crime, even if it hasn't happened yet. That's what I always say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.   Good saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He prods at the broken light with his baton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So whatcha doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're meeting someone off a flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're meeting someone off a flight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a hearse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.   It's a... surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which parts the surprise: The fact that you're in a bright yellow hearse, the fact that you're dressed like something out of a horror film, or the fact that you're half a mile from the terminal and they're gonna have to walk across two runways to reach you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is looking increasingly desperate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... the first part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop nods and repeats it to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, now why don't you tell me what the hell's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stare at each other. The cop shifts position and purses his lips. Larry stares at the ground looking for some kind of inspiration. Just when the silence moves beyond uncomfortable, the door of the mortuary opens and Phil clatters out with the casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't care if it is first thing in the morning - but I sure need a coffee. I tell you, I've never seen so many darned bits of paper to sign! It's paperwork which is slowing this great country down. We're drowning in triplicate!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's busying himself at the back of the hearse, and appea to notice the cop for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop peers at him suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mornin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just saying how people with work to do - people like yourself, officer - are just getting engulfed by paper. Grab the end, will you? Doesn't that just drive you plain crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop hesitates and then takes the end of the casket an helps load it into the hearse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess it does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil gestures at Larry to get into the car, which he does

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One casket, six sheets to sign. Six! That can't be right. Does that sound right to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He closes the back doors and gets into the passenger seat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.   Sure don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the very last thing I want to do is to hold you up further with my chatter. Thank you for your help, officer. You have a good day, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like they've got away with it.   But:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a moment, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil smiles up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your sidekick here has just finished telling me that you're gonna pick someone up from the terminal. A surprise, he said. And here you are loading a coffin into your vehicle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil doesn't miss a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there you have it, officer. You see the gentleman we're meeting from the plane doesn't yet know about the sad passing of his... aunt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're gonna meet him off his flight with her coffin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He raises an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a real nice touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. We're doing it this way for the avoidance of doubt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures at Larry to start the car. Larry pulls out th screwdriver and starts to jig it about in the ignition. The cop watches. As the engine refuses to catch, Larry starts to panic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ignition's a bit temperamental.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More fiddling.     No ignition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have to use a screwdriver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car starts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for everything, officer. We'd best be off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks meaningfully at the cop, who grudgingly moves back. As they move off, Stanley hurries round the corner with his overnight bag in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the car, Phil bangs on the dashboard in joy and exultation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!    We did it!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did what?    What did we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil changes the subject.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was all that babbling about earlier?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't babble. I just... have a problem with authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like them and I don't know what to say to them. They make me feel uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well of course they make you feel uneasy. They're supposed to make you feel uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry sulks. Phil shakes his head and glances back at the cop and Larry crashes the car straight into the hangar wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We pull back to reveal the enormous opening that Larry ha missed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both sit there, staring out of the windshield at the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hit the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I clipped it. I clipped the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) There's a gap fifty yards wide! You just had to aim for the gap. How could you miss the gap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (babbles) I was distracted. We're supposed to be picking someone up and you arrive with a coffin and I'd only just woken up and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop peers in at the window and gestures at Phil to wi it down. As he does, the glass falls out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, officer. I guess they make these hearses wider than they need to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop ignores him and concentrates on Larry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you on drugs, boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, not at this time, no sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not at this time. Okay, well let's see. You just missed a gap of fifty yards and hit a wall in broad daylight. Why was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry licks his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.   Phil wills him to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still nothing. Larry looks like he's trying to form words but nothing emerges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now I'm gonna...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The radio in his car crackles into life. We - and he - ar too far away to hear what is said. He is torn for a moment, but then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks back to his car.           Phil shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantastic.     Well done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, right.     So it's all my fault?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You... you just drove into a wall! Of course it's your fault. Jesus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both stare out of the window at the cop, who is talking animatedly into his radio. Then the flashing lights and siren go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here it comes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The police car drives up to, and then past, the hearse, before disappearing out of the hanger at speed. Phil and Larry look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what are we doing now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said to wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil just stares at him. After a moment, Larry reverses Bernice and then drives the battered car through the gap and out of the hangar. Phil slumps back in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice going, hippie. Went right through the gap that time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry says nothing.     Phil leans back in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we got it. Whoooh!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry slams the brakes on and the huge car skids to a hal in a cloud of dust. Phil is flung forward in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus... What now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks nervously out of the back window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, we gotta keep moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out and take your friend with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I can see you're a bit... sensitive about this whole... casket thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts) Stop saying that!    I can't get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... look, it's not right to throw me out onto the street with a coffin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry slips the car into gear and it moves forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry makes a U-turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm driving back to the mortuary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearly at the turn now. Phil opens the car door with a mind to jump out, but one look at the fast-moving road changes his mind. He glowers at Larry and shuts the door. The hearse skids round the corner, Larry slams on the brakes and the car slides to a halt outside the mortuary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry gestures towards the back of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's the stiff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk is standing at the counter staring at Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parsons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parsons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Long blond hair, blue eyes, mid- twenties?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was he in a Berkeley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's a Berkeley?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A luxury casket of solid mahogany, finished with a split- hinged lid, eight brass plated casket handles and an engraved inscription plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. LA DEPARTMENT OF BIRTHS MARRIAGES & DEATHS. MORN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is sitting in a cubicle opposite a middle-aged woman in a suit. Her allure appears lost on the official, who gives the dress a disapproving look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parsons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parsons.   And he's a... musician?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says 'musician' with great distaste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was.   He was a musician.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman flicks through some papers on her desk.   Barba watches her. Eventually:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid we have no official notification of death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a flourish, Barbara places a copy of the LA Times on the table. The headline is 'Country-Rock Pioneer Dead' in large black print. The official glances at it and gives a thin smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this current time, the Greater Los Angeles registrar of Births, Marriages and Deaths does not regard the local newspaper as an official recorder of record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is staring at Phil.      Waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we please talk about this later? This is not a great place to be right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry moves to get out of the car.        Phil grabs his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, just a minute. Now I understand... You think there's a body back there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think there's a body in the coffin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry watches him laugh.      Phil catches the look and s laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can fully understand why you'd think that. I mean, it is a coffin and all. But would I - would I really - steal a real live dead body?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley and the clerk are staring at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just gave the body away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's not like this is a bank. People round here don't generally take dead bodies they're not entitled to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you give it to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, he signed for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who signed for it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk peers at his paperwork.        When he eventual speaks, it is wearily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where do I find this John Nobody?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clerk's attention switches to a point just above Stanley's shoulder. He points out through the window to where the hearse is parked over a hundred yards away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is staring at Phil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely, completely, totally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looked pretty heavy, for an empty casket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are made of finest... poplar. That's very heavy wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poplar? No way?   Mahogany, or oak, but not...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I'm not going to argue with you now. Poplar is very well suited to the making of coffins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry stares hard at Phil. We see the door of the mortuar open over Larry's shoulder and Stanley and the clerk emerge. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. So why have we got an empty coffin in the back of the car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil glances at the approaching Stanley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... selling them on to a company in Palm Springs. Lots of stiffs, lots of money. And then of course, it's very environmentally sound. And... look, under the circumstances, perhaps we should renegotiate the financial arrangement between us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry still stares at Phil.      Stanley is almost at the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-fifty? That baby's worth two grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stanley is getting ever closer. Phil can see him in his wing mirror. Larry releases the safety brake and the gian car roars away, leaving Stanley standing in a cloud of dust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. LA DEPARTMENT OF BIRTHS MARRIAGES & DEATHS. MORN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara picks up the newspaper and rips it into pieces, which she scatters onto the desk. She walks towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't forget now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Notification of death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is gone, the door slamming behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry drives. Phil is still pitching.        They are dri alongside the airport runway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then Bobby transfers 'em into hardboard boxes just prior to the cremation and I drive the caskets over to a guy I know in Palm Springs who resells them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As new?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I'm not sure the 'one careful owner' thing works with coffins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole thing is completely immoral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well. I saw how outraged you were back there, when I mentioned money. Just think of it as recycling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I really need to get home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just... do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is sweating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, while I acknowledge the power of your argument, we have to be somewhere else. So just settle back and enjoy the ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry slows the car down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gas now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry pulls the car onto a Gas station forecourt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An attendant is filling Bernice.           He looks Phil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You an undertaker?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't yer surposed to be in black?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope. We're special rock 'n roll undertakers. Musical morticians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is sitting on the toilet seat - still fully dressed but bent double with cramps. Then Phil bangs on the door and calls from outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, hippie - let's roll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry turns to look at his reflection in the grimy mirror He is shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tank is full, and the attendant screws the cap back o Phil reaches into the back and pulls out his jerry can. H passes it to the guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High test.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This car runs on regular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil raises an eyebrow, glances across at the casket, and winks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says it's for the car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man gapes at him. Larry walks over to the car and Phi gets into the passenger seat. He passes some money to the attendant and takes the can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't fer the car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry jiggles the screwdriver, slips Bernice into gear, a they're gone. The attendant watches them go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Larry is driving, Phil is looking out of the window.   Th are still in a built up area with cars around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could go back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would we want to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't expecting a long trip. I haven't packed any spare clothes. We could pick up some supplies and drive out tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to go home to pick up fresh clothes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phil stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then drive back out tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just drive the car, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara is standing in her sitting room, the phone to her ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might need to repeat that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her mouth drops open and she sinks down onto her couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
